topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Melissa Perri’s experience across thousands of PMs and many companies, and Melissa shares what she focuses on now: teaching (Harvard, Product Institute), CPO Accelerator, and writing a new book on Product Operations.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Amplitude and Revenuecat, covering analytics, experimentation, CDP capabilities, and subscription infrastructure/metrics for mobile and web apps.

topics.title: Common product org problems at scale-ups
topics.summary: Melissa explains that many SaaS companies struggle most at the post–product-market-fit scale-up phase: moving from single product to multi-product, managing a portfolio, prioritizing amid endless requests, and deploying a coherent strategy across a growing org.

topics.title: When it’s time to hire a CPO
topics.summary: They discuss signals a company needs a CPO: executives/board lack visibility into product progress, teams can’t connect work to strategy, PMs are frustrated by missing direction, and hiring/training gaps emerge as the org grows.

topics.title: CPO timing: PM count, complexity, scope
topics.summary: Melissa shares practical heuristics (e.g., ARR and portfolio complexity) and notes CPO scope often includes design, product ops, analytics, and sometimes engineering—so the need depends on organizational complexity, not just PM headcount.

topics.title: VP/Head of Product vs CPO responsibilities
topics.summary: Melissa distinguishes functional product leadership (process, roadmaps, coaching) from executive-level CPO work (board communication, financial fluency, roadmap-to-revenue projection, cross-exec alignment, and broader functional oversight).

topics.title: When to bring in consultants or interim CPOs
topics.summary: Melissa explains when outside help is useful (uncertainty about what leader to hire, transformations, urgent scaling needs) and emphasizes success requires leadership ownership and willingness to make hard changes; consulting can’t substitute for executive action.

topics.title: Signs your company lacks a real strategy
topics.summary: Melissa outlines symptoms: teams working nonstop but metrics don’t move, product feels like a black box to executives, strategy lives only in heads, and there’s a “missing middle” between company goals and team-level work causing thinly spread initiatives.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Makelog, a tool to turn shipped work from systems like Linear/GitHub into bite-sized updates distributed via in-app, Slack, email, and social channels.

topics.title: What good strategy deployment looks like
topics.summary: Melissa proposes a simple test: ask teams what they’re doing and why—everyone should tell a consistent story linking tactics to customer value and business outcomes; strong strategy also reduces stakeholder infighting via shared priorities and objective trade-offs.

topics.title: Strategy artifacts: two-pagers across levels
topics.summary: They discuss lightweight documentation: executive strategic intents, product initiatives, and team-level solution options, each captured in short memos (1–2 pages) and linked in a wiki/docs so context flows up and down the strategy tree.

topics.title: Creating product vision: writing plus visuals
topics.summary: Melissa recommends combining narrative writing with visual aids (prototypes, diagrams, ecosystem maps) to make the vision tangible and align stakeholders; designers can dramatically improve clarity and shared understanding.

topics.title: How to get better at product vision
topics.summary: Melissa advises making visions concrete (not taglines), sufficiently ambitious, clearly differentiated from competitors, and explicit about what the company won’t do; she suggests brainstorming in writing to surface differentiation and target customers/value.

topics.title: How PMs build strategic thinking skills
topics.summary: Melissa suggests practicing by “thinking like the CPO,” learning leaders’ decision processes, talking to sales/finance/other functions, and grounding strategy in data and customer research—making informed bets and iterating when wrong.

topics.title: Preview: Product Operations and scaling issues
topics.summary: Melissa previews why Product Ops matters: as orgs scale, inconsistent roadmaps/processes, missing career ladders, and meeting overload create friction; Product Ops helps standardize and enable teams so strategy and execution scale.
